bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Laura Reed Blincoe, February 28, 1892

div1.p: Reed provides details of his personal finances. He relates news of his family, and he makes comments about her children. He offers his opinion regarding the religious revival at his son's school

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Laura Reed Blincoe, February 28, 1892
div1.p:
Your dear
letter of the 24th Inst, came
yesterday afternoon, so that I
am not losing much time in
answering it- What long and
interesting letters you always
write! I am willing to agree
with you that our dear father
is, in many respects, a remar-
-kable man and, in all respects,
a pure & true man, but I think
that his oldest daughter is
really a more remarkable
man than he is! Indeed, when
I think of you, as the head and
manager of a family of four
sons & five daughters, and
that you exhibit such cheerful-
ness and contentment, in the
midst of adverse circumstances,
I simply remove my hat and
say, “there is the most wonder-
ful woman of the age”! And I
mean what I say! I must tell
you, my dear Sister, that it has
been a great grief to me and
a continual “thorn in the flesh”,
that I have been unable, through
no fault of mine, to assist either
you or poor, dear Tom, in a
financial way- It is true that
I did manage to let Kit & Tom
have about $600.00, but that was
in the days before your widow-
hood. I have often wondered
whether you didn't sometimes
think hard of your youngest
brother for not coming to your
assistance- I hope not- at least,
not very often- If I only had
the $3500.00 that I lost in Florida,
in the orange adventure!-I know
that I told you all about that-
Now, at Emily's urgent request,
I am buying land for a home
in Maryland- Am paying
$60.00 a month & have been doing
so since November 1890; & when
I think that this must continue
till July 1894, I feel like al-
most “giving up the ghost”- with
the boy at school, the monthly
payments to be made aforesaid, Life In-
surance to be kept up, & house-
hold expenses to be attended
to, I feel sometimes that I
shall have to desert & skip off
to the South Sea Islands!

I merely mention these things, so
that you can see how your
little brother has to “scratch” to
make the “two ends meet”- Now,
don't misunderstand me, my
darling Sister- I don't mean
to say that you think unkindly
of your brother for his lack of
assistance- I wouldn't say this
for the world - but that your
brother blames himself very
often for not doing what is
nevertheless next to impossible
for him to do! Nevertheless, he
hopes that the time will come
when he can do more, or rather
something, & then he will respond,
oh! so gladly! I am very glad
that little Bessie has had the
operation performed- Carry out
Dr Shield's direction strictly-
Am sorry that your boys
were disappointed in not hav-
ing their salaries increased, this
year- still they shouldn't be
disappointed- Let them hold
on bravely- It will certainly
come- I am so glad that
you have them so near you
so that they have a mother's
influence. Take my advice,
my darling, & let them all of
of your boys get positions
in Richmond, if possible-
I am so glad to hear that
Nita likes her new sphere
of duty- She is a brave girl-
Give her much love for
me, when you next write
to her- Lallie must have
had a very severe attack
of Typhoid fever- She is wise
in not trying to do anything
in the way of brain work,
for the present- By hastening
slowly, she will come around
alright and can have, at least,
the satisfaction of knowing that
her chances of having a second
attack are infinitesimal!
Give her much love for
me. Am glad to know that
Tom's boy is taking hold of
his books- How his dear Papa
did despise them, when a boy!
I trust that he will not
inherit the same disposition.
Give him my love and a kiss.
So Olin is getting a “power
of larning” in his head? Why
don't you make a professor
of him? Don't he take kindly
to the ancient Sanskrit? I
think that with Sanskrit, Greek,
Latin, and a few of the modern
languages thrown in, he might
succeed in teaching “the young idea” &c
Keep the little girls at home until
they are eight or nine, & then
“hump 'em” up. Little Emily
who will be nine, next July,
is just beginning to spell. She
is a big, strong girl & is study-
ing very well & learning to write,
too. Lawrence is still at R. M.
A, but I don't think that
he will go back, next ses-
sion- Firstly, it's a long way
off, and Secondly, the Principal
has seen fit to interrupt
the boys' studies by introdu-
cing a good, old fashioned
Methodist revival- Of course,
the little fellow has “professed,”
as might be expected of any
emotional boy, although, of course,
such spasmodic religious excite=
ment is a good deal like pouring
water on a duck's back. I don't
approve of such things for children,
my darling Sister. My boy hasn't
done anything that he should be told
that he is a lost since & in danger
of hell-fire- He is loving, truth-
ful, charitable & tender-hearted- He
loves God & would share his last
crust with the hungry- I could not
help writing a sharp letter to
Dr Smith- as I had already told
him my ideas of the injury which
religious emotional excitement often
did to young boys & girls- But I must
close- Emily & daughter join me in much
love to all- Please write soon-
very soon, for I so love to hear from
you-
